results.title: Scramble
results.creator_credit: David Eady, Children's Film Foundation and Eady-Barnes Productions
results.brief_description: Jimmy has been in trouble with the police. He is befriended by a group who invite him to join the local Motorcycle Scramble Club. Jimmy and his friends become involved with a couple of crooks who attempt to sabotage the club’s chances of winning. Rated: G (

results.title: Mining
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
A detailed statement of Australia’s massive mining developments in the eighties - tin, coal, bauxite, iron ore as well as the production of the more rare metals such as gold, silver and uranium. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Commerce
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Motion Picture Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
A look at Australia’s image within the world of commerce in the 1980’s - its transportation, stock exchanges, futures markets, and its growth in the cattle, produce and minerals industries. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: Scientific cook: stale tales
results.creator_credit: Rowena Golman, A Stephens Kerr Production and Channel 4
results.brief_description: This video illustrates and discusses the answer to five scientific questions related to the principles of food preparation. 1. Why does bread go stale and what can be done to prevent this? 2. What makes a sponge cake light? 3. Why must bread dough be kneaded so much? 4. What effect does colour and texture have on the way meat should be cooked. 5. How do microwaves cook food?

results.title: Screen dreams
results.creator_credit: Bruce Martin, Stephanie Bennett, Delilah Films and Kobal Collection
results.brief_description: Since its early days, Hollywood was seen to be responsible for the phenomenal growth of two major industries: motion pictures and the Hollywood pin-up. Narrated by former pin-up girl and star of Howard Hughes’ `The Outlaw’ (1943), Jane Russell, this documentary traces the history of the pin-up, from the first studio glamour portraits to more risque and scandalous photos, staged publicity stills, and the familiar “cheesecake” and “beefcake” shots. The pin-up played a vital role in the marketing of motion pictures, a function which became more important after World War II, for reasons both of morale and propaganda. Many pin-ups gained their start in the film industry from modelling, which led to lengthy sessions in the studio portrait galleries, and sometimes, much-coveted bit parts in films. This documentary examines a wealth of archival footage in its efforts to demystify the concept of the pin-up, including segments from a charming newsreel called “Gilding the Lily”, which explains how the average woman can be transformed into a star with the correct hair and make-up. Features brief interviews with other former pin-ups, including Mamie van Doren, Tab Hunter, Dorothy Lamour and Buster Crabbe. Other stars mentioned include Theda Bara, Rita Hayworth, Mae West, Esther Williams, Lana Turner, Marilyn Monroe, Marlene Dietrich, Jayne Mansfield, Betty Grable, Ava Gardner, Greta Garbo, Anita Ekberg, Ursula Andress, Jane Fonda, Piper Laurie, Joan Collins, Alan Ladd, Cary Grant, John Payne, Errol Flynn and Johnny Weissmuller.

results.title: Science, seedbed of industry
results.creator_credit: Grant Crabtree, Mel Thistle, National Film Board of Canada and Pied Piper Films
results.brief_description: A presentation of discoveries made by scientists at Canada’s National Research Council, Ottawa, that have become patented and manufactured. The film describes the origins of some of the inventions, invites scientists to explain and looks in on factories where various items are mass-produced.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Grant Crabtree, Mel Thistle, National Film Board of Canada and Pied Piper Films

results.title: Screamin' Jay Hawkins
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Triandafyllidis, Amanda Livanou, Fenia Cossovista, Iraklis Mavroidis, Astra and Ideefixe
results.brief_description: Screamin’ Jay Hawkins (1929-2000) was a unique Afro-American musician who had a tumultuous career and a strong affiliation with voodoo. He was renowned for his eccentric live performances - emerging out of coffins on stage, and laying bones, skulls and other paraphernalia atop his piano. Along with Bo Didley, Hawkins celebrated his blackness in a way that was very rare in the 1950s and frequently alluded to jungles, cannibalism and mysticism to a degree that even alienated his black audience. Hawkins fame was much diminished when his song “I put a spell on you” was used in the Jim Jarmusch cult film “Stranger than paradise” but Hawkins had lost the rights to the song, receiving few royalties from its massive success. Jarmusch also cast Hawkins as a desk clerk in “Mystery train” (1989). This documentary features interviews with Bo Didley, Diamanda Galas, Jim Jarmusch, Andrew Williams and Eric Burden as well as producers, family and friends. Songs include: I put a spell on you (several versions), Alligator wine, Frenzy, Shout and Goodnight sweetheart. Features live footage of Hawkins on stage as well as extensive interviews with him just prior to his death.

results.title: Science international. No. 1. What is life?
results.creator_credit: Aubrey F Singer, Humphrey Fisher and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: A report on the world-wide investigation into the origins of life, as revealed in the study of the cell, and progress in the battle against cancer. Explains what is known of the nature, operation, and origin of the living human cell. Interviews and demonstrations involve scientists from Britain, the United States, France and the Soviet Union. Extensive use is made of a model of a living cell enlarged a million times.

results.title: Scream greats. Vol. 01: Tom Savini, master of horror make-up (D)
results.creator_credit: Damon Santostefano, Linda Laias and O'Quinn Productions
results.brief_description: Tom Savini who has acted and performed stunts for Hollywood productions is mostly known for his blood-curdling special effects used in horror films. “Scream greats” takes a close look at the life, influences and techniques in ‘horror’ special effects that Tom Savini brought to the screen. Tom Savini is reputed to have caused the explosion in popularity of horror films since the eighties as a result of his increasingly realistic and gory special effects devised for these films. Featured are interviews with Tom and other colleagues along with excerpts from some of the horror films in which Savini’s special effects and make-up design were central to the film, including: “Friday the 13th” series, “Day of the dead”, “Martin”, “Dawn of the dead”, “Knight riders”, “Maniac”, “Tales from the darkside” plus more.

results.title: Science in a wine glass
results.creator_credit: Jack Gardiner, John Kingsford-Smith and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description: Shows in detail, through specially made glass tanks, how wine is fermented, how fermentation is arrested, how color is infused into the red wine from skin pigmentation, how champagne is made and how wine matures. Also demonstrates how cross-pollination is effected to produce new varieties of grapes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Gardiner, John Kingsford-Smith and Kingcroft Productions
